articles.headline: Not Laid Off? How to Aid the Less Fortunate
articles.snippet: There are many ways to give support to friends and former colleagues who’ve lost their jobs.
articles.abstract: There are many ways to give support to friends and former colleagues who’ve lost their jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the signature emotions of this particular recession, besides the populist rage that boiled over this week, is a bit of survivor’s guilt.

articles.headline: The Problem With Flogging A.I.G.
articles.snippet: The anger and drama over the bonuses at A.I.G. may be undermining efforts to shore up the economy.
articles.abstract: The anger and drama over the bonuses at A.I.G. may be undermining efforts to shore up the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can we all just calm down a little?

articles.headline: Young and Old Are Facing Off for Jobs
articles.snippet: The young argue that employers favor older workers, who in turn say they are being discriminated against.
articles.abstract: The young argue that employers favor older workers, who in turn say they are being discriminated against.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — This city has become a front line in a generational battle for jobs, as older workers increasingly compete against applicants in their 20s for positions at supermarkets, McDonald’s and dozens of other places. And older workers seem to be winning.

articles.headline: Toxic Asset Plan Foresees Big Subsidies for Investors
articles.snippet: The goal of a plan to be announced next week is to leverage the dwindling resources of the bailout program with money from private investors.
articles.abstract: The goal of a plan to be announced next week is to leverage the dwindling resources of the bailout program with money from private investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Edmund L. Andrews, Eric Dash and Graham Bowley.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews, Eric Dash and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: A Town Reborn Faces a New Threat
articles.snippet: The recession has taken a heavy toll on the small businesses of Beacon, N.Y., a decade after a renewal attracted antique stores, restaurants and other shopkeepers.
articles.abstract: The recession has taken a heavy toll on the small businesses of Beacon, N.Y., a decade after a renewal attracted antique stores, restaurants and other shopkeepers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEACON, N.Y. — On a refrigerator in the back of the Cup and Saucer Tea Room here, the owner, Shirley Hot, keeps a calendar filled with notes like “Giants playoffs” or “pumpkin soup.”

articles.headline: Travelers, Your Tour Bus Is Boarding for Basra
articles.snippet: A group of Westerners has taken the first authorized tour of Iraq since 2003. Few problems were reported.
articles.abstract: A group of Westerners has taken the first authorized tour of Iraq since 2003. Few problems were reported.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Jo Rawlins Gilbert, a 79-year-old retired probation officer from Menlo Park, Calif., started traveling, as she put it, “as most people do.”

articles.headline: New Honda Takes on the Prius
articles.snippet: The Honda Insight, to be introduced on Tuesday, is being positioned as a more affordable hybrid car.
articles.abstract: The Honda Insight, to be introduced on Tuesday, is being positioned as a more affordable hybrid car.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  The road is about to get a little more crowded for the Toyota Prius. Starting Tuesday, the Honda Motor Company will offer American consumers what it bills as “the world’s first affordable hybrid.”

articles.headline: Natural Gas, Suddenly Abundant, Is Cheaper
articles.snippet: The first globalized natural gas glut in history is driving an even more drastic collapse in the cost of gas that cooks food, heats homes and runs factories in the U.S. and many other countries.
articles.abstract: The first globalized natural gas glut in history is driving an even more drastic collapse in the cost of gas that cooks food, heats homes and runs factories in the U.S. and many other countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  The decline in crude oil prices gets all the headlines, but the first globalized natural gas glut in history is driving an even more drastic collapse in the cost of gas that cooks food, heats homes and runs factories in the United States and many other countries.

articles.headline: Is a Food Revolution Now in Season?
articles.snippet: Advocates of organic and locally grown food have found a receptive ear in the White House, which has vowed to encourage a more nutritious and sustainable food supply.
articles.abstract: Advocates of organic and locally grown food have found a receptive ear in the White House, which has vowed to encourage a more nutritious and sustainable food supply.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif.

articles.headline: Red Flags That Muni Investors Can’t See
articles.snippet: Full disclosure, that bedrock of fair securities markets, is the heart of the problem facing municipal investors.
articles.abstract: Full disclosure, that bedrock of fair securities markets, is the heart of the problem facing municipal investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAMMERED by turbulent stock prices, investors have retreated in recent months to the relative safety of good old municipal bonds. Trading in this $2.7 trillion market rose 22 percent in 2008.

articles.headline: Its Population Falling, Russia Beckons Its Children Home
articles.snippet: The government is trying to head off a severe population decline by luring back Russians from as far as Uruguay.
articles.abstract: The government is trying to head off a severe population decline by luring back Russians from as far as Uruguay.
articles.lead_paragraph: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia — Vasily Reutov had never set foot in Russia until a few months ago, but the moment he did, he knew he had finally made it home.

articles.headline: A Slippery Place in the U.S. Work Force
articles.snippet: Many immigrants from Latin America are learning how uncertain their foothold is in the job market in the United States.
articles.abstract: Many immigrants from Latin America are learning how uncertain their foothold is in the job market in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: MORRISTOWN, Tenn. — The faithful stand and hold their hands high, raising a crescendo of prayer for abundance and grace. In the evangelical church where they are gathered, the folding chairs are filled with immigrants from Latin America.

articles.headline: Harley, You’re Not Getting Any Younger
articles.snippet: With its sales down and its core audience graying, Harley-Davidson, once a revered American brand, may need to redefine itself.
articles.abstract: With its sales down and its core audience graying, Harley-Davidson, once a revered American brand, may need to redefine itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPUCK BENNETT’S dealership just outside Ocean City, Md., is cluttered with 65 shiny Harley-Davidson motorcycles, including the chrome Sportster and the sleek V-Rod. Last year, Mr. Bennett, 79, sold 200 bikes, down from 280 the year before. This year, sales have slowed to a crawl.

articles.headline: Administration Seeks Increase in Oversight of Executive Pay
articles.snippet: The sweeping regulatory plan is also expected to call for the Federal Reserve to oversee hedge funds whose problems could pose risks to the entire financial system.
articles.abstract: The sweeping regulatory plan is also expected to call for the Federal Reserve to oversee hedge funds whose problems could pose risks to the entire financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration will call for increased oversight of executive pay at all banks, Wall Street firms and possibly other companies as part of a sweeping plan to overhaul financial regulation, government officials said.

articles.headline: In Austin, a Thriving Weekly With a Mission
articles.snippet: The Austin Chronicle is more than a cultural newsweekly. It’s an engine of culture, and a solvent one, too.
articles.abstract: The Austin Chronicle is more than a cultural newsweekly. It’s an engine of culture, and a solvent one, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every day at the South by Southwest conference in Austin last week, I would leave my hotel room for events, and at each door in the hall, there would be various copies of complimentary newspapers. For the whole week, none of them, ever, seemed to be picked up. Over the course of a few days, as the Web and film conference gave way to the music festival, the papers sat, still as gravestones and almost as ominous.

articles.headline: In Hollywood, the Easy-Money Generation Toughens Up
articles.snippet: After two decades of almost nonstop growth from cable and video, a new generation of Hollywood power players is testing its mettle.
articles.abstract: After two decades of almost nonstop growth from cable and video, a new generation of Hollywood power players is testing its mettle.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif. — In the bungalow offices here that house Steven Spielberg’s newly formed DreamWorks Studios, the swagger is suddenly being dialed back a notch or two.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: As Rights Clash on YouTube, Some Music Vanishes
articles.snippet: Some videos on YouTube are disappearing in a disagreement over fees for Warner Music’s copyrighted works.
articles.abstract: Some videos on YouTube are disappearing in a disagreement over fees for Warner Music’s copyrighted works.
articles.lead_paragraph: In early December, Juliet Weybret, a high school sophomore and aspiring rock star from Lodi, Calif., recorded a video of herself playing the piano and singing “Winter Wonderland,” and she posted it on YouTube.

articles.headline: Trade Barriers Rise as Slump Tightens Grip
articles.snippet: A surge in protectionism is provoking nasty trade disputes and undermining efforts to plot a coordinated response to the global economic downturn.
articles.abstract: A surge in protectionism is provoking nasty trade disputes and undermining efforts to plot a coordinated response to the global economic downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After repeated pledges by world leaders to avoid erecting trade barriers, protectionism is on the march, provoking nasty trade disputes and undermining efforts to plot a coordinated response to the deepest global economic downturn since World War II.

articles.headline: At A.I.G., the Brand Is Tarnished
articles.snippet: The damage done to A.I.G.’s brand has competitors circling to snap up its customers, but not to buy its insurance divisions.
articles.abstract: The damage done to A.I.G.’s brand has competitors circling to snap up its customers, but not to buy its insurance divisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government’s fourth round of assistance to the American International Group this month was a play for time  for languishing markets to rebound, for pockets to fill up again and for buyers to emerge for the sturdy insurance companies under A.I.G.’s tattered corporate umbrella.

articles.headline: Sweden Says No to Saving Saab
articles.snippet: The carmaker has fallen on hard times in a country where Nordic socialism has fallen out of favor.
articles.abstract: The carmaker has fallen on hard times in a country where Nordic socialism has fallen out of favor.
articles.lead_paragraph: TROLLHATTAN, Sweden — Saab Automobile may be just another crisis-ridden car company in an industry full of them. But just as the fortunes of Flint, Mich., are permanently entangled with General Motors, so it is impossible to find anyone in this city in southwest Sweden who is not somehow connected to Saab.

articles.headline: Energy Secretary Serves Under a Microscope
articles.snippet: Steven Chu has likened his introduction to Washington to being “dumped in the deep end of the pool.”
articles.abstract: Steven Chu has likened his introduction to Washington to being “dumped in the deep end of the pool.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a physicist, Steven Chu has seen atoms suspended in a powerful laser beam and DNA stretched out in a vacuum chamber.

articles.headline: Stimulus Ideals Conflict on the Texas Prairie
articles.snippet: A proposed toll road near Houston exemplifies an unintended effect of the federal stimulus law: encouraging sprawl.
articles.abstract: A proposed toll road near Houston exemplifies an unintended effect of the federal stimulus law: encouraging sprawl.
articles.lead_paragraph: WALLER, Tex. — Over the years the Katy Prairie has survived the cattle ranchers who tamed its fields, the rice farmers who cleared its wildflowers and tall grasses, and even the encroachment of Houston, some 30 miles to the east, whose spiraling outward growth turned most of the formerly lonesome prairie into subdivisions and strip malls.

articles.headline: U.S. Rounding Up Investors to Buy Bad Assets
articles.snippet: A day before unveiling the government’s plan to buy troubled assets, the Obama administration worked to persuade private investors to participate.
articles.abstract: A day before unveiling the government’s plan to buy troubled assets, the Obama administration worked to persuade private investors to participate.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Andrew Ross Sorkin, Eric Dash and Rachel L. Swarns.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Eric Dash and Rachel L. Swarns

articles.headline: Rivals Say I.B.M. Stifles Competition to Mainframes
articles.snippet: Big Blue is being criticized for buying a company whose technology could have paved the way for cheaper competition in the mainframe marketplace.
articles.abstract: Big Blue is being criticized for buying a company whose technology could have paved the way for cheaper competition in the mainframe marketplace.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  I.B.M. has dominated the mainframe computer business since the category was created four decades ago. And it still gets about one-quarter of its $100 billion in annual revenue from sales, software, services and financing related to the machines.

articles.headline: Mexican Drug Cartel Violence Spills Over, Alarming U.S.
articles.snippet: Tucson is coping with a wave of drug crime the police suspect is tied to the battles between Mexico’s drug cartels.
articles.abstract: Tucson is coping with a wave of drug crime the police suspect is tied to the battles between Mexico’s drug cartels.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON — Sgt. David Azuelo stepped gingerly over the specks of blood on the floor, took note of the bullet hole through the bedroom skylight, raised an eyebrow at the lack of furniture in the ranch-style house and turned to his squad of detectives investigating one of the latest home invasions in this southern Arizona city.

articles.headline: U.S. Expands Plan to Buy Banks’ Troubled Assets
articles.snippet: The Treasury presented its plan to draw private investors into partnership with a new federal entity to buy up risky assets.
articles.abstract: The Treasury presented its plan to draw private investors into partnership with a new federal entity to buy up risky assets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration’s new plan to liberate the nation’s banks from a toxic stew of bad home loans and mortgage-related securities is bigger and more generous to private investors than expected, but it also puts taxpayers at great risk.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Eric Dash
